channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Elon Musk tells federal employees to document work in email or be fired
item.description: Federal workers across the U.S. government received an email on Saturday, with an apparent ultimatum. Musk has used a similar tactic at companies he owns.
item.content:encoded:
Federal workers across the U.S. government received an email on Saturday, with an apparent ultimatum. Musk has used a similar tactic at companies he owns.

(Image credit: Jose Luis Magana)
item.dc:creator: Brett Neely

item.title: Who is Trump's pick for chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, Dan Caine?
item.description: Caine is a career fighter jet pilot who defended Washington, D.C., during the 9/11 attacks and been adored by Trump since they met in Iraq during Trump's first term.
item.content:encoded:
Caine is a career fighter jet pilot who defended Washington, D.C., during the 9/11 attacks and been adored by Trump since they met in Iraq during Trump's first term.

(Image credit: U.S. Air Force)
item.dc:creator: Juliana Kim

item.title: Pope Francis is in critical condition, the Vatican says
item.description: The 88-year-old Francis has been hospitalized for a week with a complex lung infection.
item.content:encoded:
The 88-year-old Francis has been hospitalized for a week with a complex lung infection.

(Image credit: Gregorio Borgia)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Week in politics: Trump's policy towards Ukraine, mass firings at federal agencies
item.description: We look at President Trump's embrace of Vladimir Putin as he turns his back on U.S. ally, Ukraine, as well as mass firings at government agencies and how that will affect the services they provide.
item.content:encoded: We look at President Trump's embrace of Vladimir Putin as he turns his back on U.S. ally, Ukraine, as well as mass firings at government agencies and how that will affect the services they provide.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: NIH funding freeze stalls applications on $1.5 billion in medical research funds
item.description: The National Institutes of Health had to stop considering new grant applications, delaying funding for research into diseases ranging from heart disease and cancer to Alzheimer's and allergies.
item.content:encoded:
The National Institutes of Health had to stop considering new grant applications, delaying funding for research into diseases ranging from heart disease and cancer to Alzheimer's and allergies.

(Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: Opinion: Amazon to deliver a new James Bond
item.description: Amazon has acquired the creative license to the long-running James Bond franchise. But how do they plan to deliver?
item.content:encoded:
Amazon has acquired the creative license to the long-running James Bond franchise. But how do they plan to deliver?

(Image credit: Michael Sohn)
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Burnout is a problem for caseworkers serving unhoused people
item.description: People who provide assistance to the unhoused often feel traumatized by their work.
item.content:encoded:
People who provide assistance to the unhoused often feel traumatized by their work.

(Image credit: Tyler Russell)
item.dc:creator: Abigail Brone

item.title: Trump administration plans mass firing at office that funds homelessness programs
item.description: Staffing at the HUD office that pays for housing and support services across the country is slated to be cut by 84%. Advocates warn such heavy cuts could make record-high homelessness even worse.
item.content:encoded:
Staffing at the HUD office that pays for housing and support services across the country is slated to be cut by 84%. Advocates warn such heavy cuts could make record-high homelessness even worse.

(Image credit: Jeff Chiu)
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Ludden

item.title: How many fourth-graders does it take to make a podcast? Here's what we learned
item.description: Students in an elementary school broadcasting club in California are among the youngest winners of NPR's Student Podcast Challenge.
item.content:encoded:
Students in an elementary school broadcasting club in California are among the youngest winners of NPR's Student Podcast Challenge.

(Image credit: Alan Nakkash for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Janet W. Lee

item.title: Elon Musk blurs the line between his government and business roles
item.description: The tech titan and President Trump say they will avoid any conflicts of interest, but it's difficult for the public to verify that.
item.content:encoded:
The tech titan and President Trump say they will avoid any conflicts of interest, but it's difficult for the public to verify that.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith
